awd_titl_txt: Incidence Theorems: Beyond the Polynomial Method
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to study basic properties of geometric arrangements, composed of lines, points, circles, and other geometric objects in which there is an abundance of ''incidences''. Here, an incidence is a small sub-configuration in which some coincidence occurs (for  example, many points lying on a single line or many lines passing through a single point). Structures that include many incidences are important in many settings such as coding theory, data storage, computational complexity, and pure mathematics.  The study of these structures was accelerated several years ago in work by the PI, who introduced the ''Polynomial Method'' to this area. This method works by modeling a given configuration as a set of solutions to an algebraic equation. This allows one to use tools from algebraic geometry to analyze the underlying incidence structure. Despite its success, several important problems remained largely impervious to the polynomial method. This project is aimed at making progress on problems in which the polynomial method fails (partially or completely) by augmenting or modifying the method or, in some cases, replacing it all together. The project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.

The main research objectives of the proposal include (1) extensions of the polynomial method to tackle incidences of high-dimensional flats and the use of these bounds to give new explicit constructions of graphs with pseudo-random properties, (2) extending the polynomial method to problems defined over rings with zero divisors, where the original method fails completely, (3) understanding the Kakeya problem for arithmetic progressions - one of the approaches to the famous Euclidean Kakeya conjecture, and (4) studying ''approximate'' (or noisy) incidence problems over the real numbers by developing robust analogs of the polynomial method. Within these areas, the project focuses on several concrete challenges and open problems, each requiring new techniques that go beyond the polynomial method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Kakeya sets possess two contradictory properties: On the one hand, they contain a straight line (of some fixed length) in every possible direction. On the other hand, they are very small (their area is close to zero). Questions about the structure of such sets arise in many areas of mathematics and computer science. They are related to problems in number theory, differential equations and even algorithms. In recent years, tremendous progress was made in studying finitary variants of Kakeya sets, namely those arising over finite fields (as opposed to the field of real numbers which is infinite).  In these finite geometries, a powerful method, known as the `polynomial method' (introduced to this area by the PI in 2008) can be used to solve long standing open problems.

The main goal of the current project was to further extend the polynomial method to tackle instances that remain beyond reach. At the conclusion of the project, two major open problems were resolved. The first extends the polynomial method from finite fields to finite rings which resemble the real numbers in some respects (since they have a notion of distance or size). The other problem which was resolved allows one to replace lines (in every direction) with higher dimensional objects (planes etc.. in every possible angle). Progress on both of these problems was communicated in several research papers published in leading peer-reviewed mathematical journals.

In addition to these purely mathematical results, new applications  were found to well studied problems in  theoretical computer science and cryptography. In particular, the PI and graduate student discovered a close connection between high dimensional Kakeya sets and fundamental behavior of linear hash functions, which have numerous applications in CS. The progress on this question was published at the leading  peer-reviewed conference in theoretical computer science.
